body:
Hi Sid,

After compiling it successfully, I seem to get a different error when running the client program.  Here are my steps:

``` Bash
$ git clone https://github.com/grpc/grpc.git
$ cd grpc
$ git submodule update --init
$ make
$
$ mkdir googleapis
$ cd googleapis
$ git clone https://github.com/googleapis/googleapis
$ cd googleapis
$ make all
$
$ cd gens
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../../include -I. ./google/genomics/v1/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../../include -I. ./google/api/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../../include -I. ./google/longrunning/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../../include -I. ./google/rpc/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../../include -I. ./google/iam/v1/*cc
$
$ g++ -std=c++11 -L/usr/lib -L../../libs/opt -L/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib -I./gens -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../include -lgrpc++ -lprotobuf -lgrpc -lgpr -lboringssl client.cc gens/*.o -o client
$
$ chmod +x client
$ 
$ ./client
./client: symbol lookup error: ./client: undefined symbol: _ZN4grpc24g_core_codegen_interfaceE
$
```

N.B.: When generating the code through `protoc` for the [Google APIs](https://github.com/googleapis/googleapis), the `make all` ends in the following error, though it does not affect the code for the Genomics API and its dependencies for the above compilation:

```
protoc --proto_path=.:/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include --cpp_out=./gens --grpc_out=./gens --plugin=protoc-gen-grpc=../../bins/opt/grpc_cpp_plugin /home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include/google/protobuf/compiler/plugin.proto
[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/io/printer.cc:148]  Undefined variable: NAME", and will then be used when the
// flag "--
```

~p
Paul, maybe your binary can not find the grpc library at runtime. You can check with `ldd client`.

Hmm, that seems to look okay:

```
$ ldd client
        linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x00007ffff7ffe000)

        libprotobuf.so.10 => /home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib/libprotobuf.so.10 (0x00007ffff799b000)

        libm.so.6 => /lib64/libm.so.6 (0x00000031e8200000)

        libc.so.6 => /lib64/libc.so.6 (0x00000031e7600000)
        libpthread.so.0 => /lib64/libpthread.so.0 (0x00000031e7a00000)
        librt.so.1 => /lib64/librt.so.1 (0x00000031e7e00000)
        libz.so.1 => /lib64/libz.so.1 (0x00000031e8600000)
        /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00000031e6e00000)
        libdl.so.2 => /lib64/libdl.so.2 (0x00000031e7200000)
$
```

I had to move around the order of the loading of the libraries, and now I'm seeing your error too, but the backtrace looks slightly different:

$ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:../../libs/opt:../../libs/protobuf:/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib
$ export GRPC_DEFAULT_SSL_ROOTS_FILE_PATH=/home/pgrosu/apps/grpc/etc/roots.pem
./client
$ ./client

Now the fun begins :)

Very interesting...  I added the following log outputs to the `timer.c`:

``` C
  gpr_log(GPR_DEBUG, "deadline.clock_type: %u", deadline.clock_type);
  gpr_log(GPR_DEBUG, "g_clock_type: %u", g_clock_type);
```

And the output shows they pass several times, but then they get out of sync on a fourth pass:

```
D0629 16:16:43.667872558   32410 timer.c:188]                deadline.clock_type: 0
D0629 16:16:43.667899581   32410 timer.c:189]                g_clock_type: 0
D0629 16:16:43.692185554   32409 timer.c:188]                deadline.clock_type: 0
D0629 16:16:43.692211200   32409 timer.c:189]                g_clock_type: 0
D0629 16:16:43.747233789   32422 timer.c:188]                deadline.clock_type: 0
D0629 16:16:43.747258075   32422 timer.c:189]                g_clock_type: 0
D0629 16:16:43.789857086   32409 timer.c:188]                deadline.clock_type: 1
D0629 16:16:43.789882469   32409 timer.c:189]                g_clock_type: 0
```

Now we have to figure out how `stub->SearchReads(&context, request, &response)` causes the last communication to become out of sync.

~p
Thanks Paul. Let's wait for a reply from someone.

While we wait, it doesn't hurt to keep trying :)  So I got it to run if I do the following change to [httpcli.c on lines 206-207](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/b6163dfb4af3bf11df6cf3f051015ec3ee4a0f68/src/core/lib/http/httpcli.c#L206-207):

Before the change:

``` C
  }
  req->handshaker->handshake(
```

After the change:

``` C
  }

  gpr_log(GPR_DEBUG, "req->request_text: %s", req->host);
  gpr_log(GPR_DEBUG, "req->deadline.clock_type: %i", req->deadline.clock_type);

  req->deadline.clock_type = GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC;

  req->handshaker->handshake(
```

Below is the output:

```
$ ./client
D0629 22:14:05.311810468    8495 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0629 22:14:05.312183203    8495 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used

E0629 22:14:05.777883352    8495 chttp2_transport.c:1820]    close_transport: {"created":"@1467252845.775822715","description":"Secure read failed","file":"src/core/lib/security/transport/secure_endpoint.c","file_line":157,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1467252845.775801855","description":"FD shutdown","file":"src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epoll_linux.c","file_line":948}]}
```

After the above change, are you getting the proper response data?

Just out of curiosity, if you set the following environment variable to your appropriate JSON file without changing any of the gRPC code, does it run for you?

```
export GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS="/path/to/keyfile.json"
```

Hi Sid,

So I finally fixed it, and got it to work!  Here's the solution, but I'll need to ask for your help to submit a PR to fix the code instead of me.   So here's the solution:

If you look at [line 451 of surface/completion_queue.c](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/cdac58bb03e060668b32836bb60a8e629cf39049/src/core/lib/surface/completion_queue.c#L451), you'll notice that the `clock_type` for `deadline` is always set to `GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC`, which is equivalent to value 0 as defined in [impl/codegen/time.h](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d0fbba52d6e379b76a69016bc264b96a2318315f/include/grpc/impl/codegen/time.h#L51):

``` C
  deadline = gpr_convert_clock_type(deadline, GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC);
```

I then updated [lines 206-207 of http/httpcli.c](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/b6163dfb4af3bf11df6cf3f051015ec3ee4a0f68/src/core/lib/http/httpcli.c#L206-207):

From:

``` C
  }
  req->handshaker->handshake(
```

To the following, since it will periodically switch to 1 (`GPR_CLOCK_REALTIME`):

``` C
  }

  req->deadline = gpr_convert_clock_type(req->deadline, GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC);

  req->handshaker->handshake(
```

Now when I run it, I get no errors:

```
$ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:../libs/opt:../libs/opt/protobuf:/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib
$ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib
$ export GRPC_DEFAULT_SSL_ROOTS_FILE_PATH=/home/pgrosu/apps/grpc/etc/roots.pem
$ export GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS=ya...[my access token]...
$ ./client
D0701 00:07:26.029894104   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0701 00:07:26.030264670   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
I0701 00:07:26.030323997   24073 ev_epoll_linux.c:84]        epoll engine will be using signal: 36
D0701 00:07:26.030366348   24073 ev_posix.c:106]             Using polling engine: epoll
D0701 00:07:26.030450124   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0701 00:07:26.030504689   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0701 00:07:26.030634770   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0701 00:07:26.032598116   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0701 00:07:26.034345462   24073 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
$
```

Voil√†!  Now if I could ask your help to submit a PR by you to update the code, that would be very appreciated.

Many thanks!
Paul

Hi Sid,

Since the default `clock_type` is `GPR_CLOCK_REALTIME` for the default constructor of the [ClientContext class](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/b6163dfb4af3bf11df6cf3f051015ec3ee4a0f68/src/cpp/client/client_context.cc#L65), even if I add this line to switch the `clock_type` to `GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC`, it still has no effect during the request process:

``` C++
context.set_deadline(gpr_inf_future(GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC));
```

So it seems that we still would need to go with the gRPC code fix.

~p

Hi Paul, sorry I was out on vacation and did not set up an out-of-office responder for github.

Thanks for all your efforts. Let me take a look at the semantics of the clock types and what they are supposed to do where. I will need to be able to make an argument of what the bug is (e.g. the design is for the clock type to be set where you say it should be set but was missed by accident) and what the proper fix is, so that it does not break anything for someone else in order to fix this one.

Oh I thought you were suggesting this as a proper fix because you wanted a pull request made out of this. This was not urgent, I created this bug to report to the grpc team that code that should have worked is not working and maybe there is a bug that could be affecting other systems too.

The idea is that a default grpc installation should work for the Genomics API. Creating another branch in our forked repos does not solve the problem.

Well, [grpc](https://github.com/grpc/grpc) currently has 19 branches - including one for an [interim release for TensorFlow](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/tensor-flow-interim-release) - so a fork/PR can still be performed when needed.  I know we should have an elegant solution, which might take a little longer - unless there a simple option to do it that we might discover - but in the meantime there is a solution to work with, until it gets updated in the master branch.  From the last user's call the gRPC Google team sounded quite overwhelmed and asked for help, which hopefully this might provide helpful ideas towards that.  At least it helped me brush up more on the internals of the core gRPC code since last year :)
Let me see if I can get a proper fix. Thanks for your help Paul.
Sounds good - I'll also keep looking in case I get any ideas of gentler approaches.
Feel free to ping me anytime if you need anything.

I finally had some time to dig into this issue today. The bug seems to have been introduced by ae134945ad935c83c0c32199be115632dd0f3b4b.

In calling grpc_timer_init from handshake.c, the deadline needs to be passed after being converted to the type GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC, and the now timespec (last arg) also needs to be constructed with this type.

It seems like SSL handshake in general would be broken by this issue, hence changed the name.

By fixing this, the above code works perfectly.

Hi Sid,

That's a great find!  How did you determine that specific code change?  By the way, you don't need to update the last `gpr_timespec` argument of `gpr_now(deadline.clock_type)` in the code - if it is properly preupdated - as the `deadline.clock_type` is propagated through the `gpr_now()` function within [time_posix.c](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/lib/support/time_posix.c#L145-L149) as follows:

``` C
gpr_timespec (*gpr_now_impl)(gpr_clock_type clock_type) = now_impl;

gpr_timespec gpr_now(gpr_clock_type clock_type) {
  return gpr_now_impl(clock_type);
}
```

The `now_impl()` pointed function - at least for Linux - will basically `return gpr_from_timespec(now, clock_type)`, which just overwrites the `clock_type` with the same value as follows:

``` C
static gpr_timespec gpr_from_timespec(struct timespec ts,
                                      gpr_clock_type clock_type) {
  /*
   * timespec.tv_sec can have smaller size than gpr_timespec.tv_sec,
   * but we are only using this function to implement gpr_now
   * so there's no need to handle "infinity" values.
   */
  gpr_timespec rv;
  rv.tv_sec = ts.tv_sec;
  rv.tv_nsec = (int32_t)ts.tv_nsec;
  rv.clock_type = clock_type;
  return rv;
}
```

If you just update [lines 359-361 in `handshake.c`](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/lib/security/transport/handshake.c#L359-L361) to the following - utilizing the `gpr_convert_clock_type()` to update the `clock_type` for `deadline` - then everything propagates properly:

``` C
  send_handshake_bytes_to_peer(exec_ctx, h);

  deadline = gpr_convert_clock_type(deadline, GPR_CLOCK_MONOTONIC);

  grpc_timer_init(exec_ctx, &h->timer, deadline, on_timeout, h,
                  gpr_now(deadline.clock_type));
```

And of course the `client.cc` will also naturally run :)

``` Bash
$ ./client
D0720 11:49:45.625022779   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0720 11:49:45.625404528   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
I0720 11:49:45.625451902   35972 ev_epoll_linux.c:85]        epoll engine will be using signal: 36
D0720 11:49:45.625489055   35972 ev_posix.c:106]             Using polling engine: epoll
D0720 11:49:45.625613394   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0720 11:49:45.625672254   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0720 11:49:45.625761591   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0720 11:49:45.626389772   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used
D0720 11:49:45.627259762   35972 env_linux.c:77]             Warning: insecure environment read function 'getenv' used

The Read ID is: ChZDTXZuaHBLVEZoRHE5ZTJZeTlHLUJnEgIxNxi3tdITKAA
The Fragment Name is: SRR584004.2808039
The Aligned Sequence is: ATCATTACCCCCATTTTACAGAGTGGGAGACTGAAGCACAGTGAAAAGGCTCTGAGAAAGTCGGCTGGCCTAAGTCTCAAGAACAGTCATTCATGGTGGAA

$
```

So do you think a PR might now be appropriate? :)

Thanks,
~p

Thanks for reporting and debugging. I think this is a bug and just sent out #7477 to fix that (which is pretty much just what @pgrosu suggested). 

Though this code is shared among all security handshake, others do not break because they already use the right clock_type before calling into the handshake code. I think your code hit the path where an oauth token needs to be fetched and the httpcli_get or post calls get their deadline from the credentials, where realtime clock_type is used often.

Hi Yang,

Thank you for helping us with the fix.  It is indeed the `grpc_httpcli_post()` function that is performing this.  I added the following line between [lines 304-305 in httpcli.c](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/lib/http/httpcli.c#L304-L305):

``` C
 gpr_log(GPR_DEBUG, "HTTP:POST: \n host:%s , \n req_path:%s , \n deadline.clock_type: %u", request->host, request->http.path, deadline.clock_type);
```

And when I ran the client, it does indeed return back a `clock_type` of 1 for `deadline`:

```
D0720 14:49:11.068975099   39253 httpcli.c:306]              HTTP:POST:
 host:www.googleapis.com ,
 req_path:/oauth2/v3/token ,
 deadline.clock_type: 1
```

It was a fun team effort :)

Thank you,
Paul

Perfect! Thank you Yang. Your commit is exactly what we need here. I have changed the name of the issue to reflect that only the path for OAuth token was affected by this.

Thank you Paul for helping throughout the process.
Verified resolved.
Most excellent - thanks Sid :)

@yyh-graphsql, @crazyproger So there are six assumptions to my compilation steps, and very specific in terms of the `googleapis` that I needed to compile for my client, which might be different than yours:
- The `googleapis` directory is within your `grpc` directory
- That you've updated the `Makefile` for the `googleapis` with the following:
  
  `GPRCPLUGIN ?=  ../bins/opt/grpc_cpp_plugin`
  `PROTOINCLUDE ?= /home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include`
- That `grpc` is already compiled, with the following steps performed for placing the appropriate files into my public `grpc` directory, like this:

```
cd ~/apps/grpc
cd bin
cp -r ~/proj/grpc/bins/ .
cd ../lib/
cp -r ~/proj/grpc/libs/opt/ .
mv opt/* .
cd ../include/
cp -r ~/proj/grpc/include/ .
cd ..
cp -r ~/proj/grpc/etc/ .
```
- The client program is called `client.cc`
- ProtoBuf is installed in `/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf`

Below are my compilation steps:

```
$ cd googleapis
$ cd gens
$ rm *.o
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../include -I. ./google/genomics/v1/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../include -I. ./google/api/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../include -I. ./google/longrunning/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../include -I. ./google/rpc/*cc
$ g++ -c -std=c++11 -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../../include -I. ./google/iam/v1/*cc
$ cd ..
$ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:../libs/opt:../libs/opt/protobuf:/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib
$ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib
$ export GRPC_DEFAULT_SSL_ROOTS_FILE_PATH=/home/pgrosu/apps/grpc/etc/roots.pem
$ g++ -std=c++11 -L/usr/lib -L../libs/opt -L/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/lib -I./gens -I/home/pgrosu/apps/protobuf/include -I../include -lgrpc++ -lprotobuf  client.cc gens/*.o -o client ; ./client
```

The order of the libraries makes a difference in how things get compiled, which was something I had to remember from my Computer Systems course :)

Please ask any questions if there is anything you need help with, and again I apologize for answering so late.

Hope it helps,
~p
